Award.AwardTitle: Electrical Discharge Machining of Biomedical Nitinol Alloys and the Resulting Fundamental Relationship of Microstructure-Property-Function

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The research objective of this proposal is to understand the basic relationship between machining conditions, white layer (that is, recast layer), and fatigue and corrosion by electrical discharge machining of biomedical Nitinol alloys by bringing together complementary international research and education expertise. It will test the hypothesis that electrical discharge machining using minimum discharge energy is a very competitive process compared to mechanical machining to economically fabricate delicate burr-free Nitinol microstructures with high aspect ratio and excellent surface finish. The research approaches are to: (1) explore the process capability in electrical discharge machining of biomedical Nitinol alloys to establish a basic relationship between processing conditions and surface integrity; (2) determine whether the white layer is metastable nano-quasicrystal using transmission electron microscopy and x-ray diffraction; (3) clarify the fundamental role of process-induced surface integrity, white layer in particular, on fatigue and corrosion performance; and (4) reveal material erosion mechanism and microstructural evolution in electrical discharging via a multiphysics process simulation approach with the capability of material ablation.

The research results will have a wide spectrum of impacts on machining of a broad range of other difficult-to-cut materials including titanium, Inconel, stainless steel, and hardened alloys. The sound sustainable practices in electrical discharge machining of metallic biomaterials can bring business value to biomedical device industry as well as tool, gas turbine, chemical and oil industries. The project will establish a synergistic education network between the University of Alabama and Aachen University to train the next cadre of ?whole-brain? students in the global context. The collaborative network will also provide an express way for fast technology transfer from fundamental research to industrial practices.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project has brought together The University of Alabama and RWTH Aachen University for providing a clear understanding of the processing-microstructure-property-function relationship in EDM of biomedical Nitinol alloys. Specifically, the project outcomes are as follows:

(1) Explored the EDM process capability in machining of biomedical Nitinol alloys to establish a basic relationship between processing conditions and surface integrity (surface micro topography, surface finish, micro crack, white layer microstructure, residual stress, micro/nano-hardness, and chemical compositions).

(2) Tested the hypothesis of metastable nano-quasicrystal white layers using optical microscopy, transmission electron microscopy (TEM), and x-ray diffraction (XRD).

(3) Elucidated the fundamental role of EDM-induced surface integrity, white layer in particular, on fatigue and corrosion performance.

(4) Developed a multiphysics EDM simulation approach with the capability of material ablation to reveal material erosion mechanism, microstructural evolution, and surface integrity.

(5) Established a synergistic international network to facilitate integrated research and education on biomaterials processing and medical device manufacturing.

 

This project has made several unique technical contributions including: (i) an efficient net-shape process to machine challenging Nitinol alloys and various other metallic biomaterials such as titanium, cobalt-chromium, and stainless steel alloys; (ii) a clear understanding of the processing-surface integrity-function relationship and the long-term confusing microstructure of white/recast layer; and (iii) a new multiphysics simulation method to shed light into the fundamental mechanism of material erosion and predict rim zone properties.

 

In addition to the above intellectual merits, this project also has a wide spectrum of impacts in medical device industry as well as tool, gas turbine, chemical and oil industries. The sound sustainable practices in EDM of metallic biomaterials will bring business value, which helps boost the competitiveness of the U.S. and German biomedical device manufacturing industries. It will also help to improve patient’s wellbeing and relieve financial burdens on our healthcare systems. The broad international dissemination will provide an express way for fast technology transfer from fundamental research to industrial practices. The US-Germany network will train the next cadre of “whole-brain” researchers in the global context. In addition, the synergy adds value to both research communities.

 


Last Modified: 11/29/2016
Modified by: Yuebin Guo

Specifically, the project outcomes are as follows: (1) Explored the EDM process capability in machining of biomedical Nitinol alloys to establish a basic relationship between processing conditions and surface integrity (surface micro topography, surface finish, micro crack, white layer microstructure, residual stress, micro/nano-hardness, and chemical compositions). (4) Developed a multiphysics EDM simulation approach with the capability of material ablation to reveal material erosion mechanism, microstructural evolution, and surface integrity. (5) Established a synergistic international network to facilitate integrated research and education on biomaterials processing and medical device manufacturing. This project has made several unique technical contributions including: (i) an efficient net-shape process to machine challenging Nitinol alloys and various other metallic biomaterials such as titanium, cobalt-chromium, and stainless steel alloys; (ii) a clear understanding of the processing-surface integrity-function relationship and the long-term confusing microstructure of white/recast layer; and (iii) a new multiphysics simulation method to shed light into the fundamental mechanism of material erosion and predict rim zone properties. In addition to the above intellectual merits, this project also has a wide spectrum of impacts in medical device industry as well as tool, gas turbine, chemical and oil industries. The broad international dissemination will provide an express way for fast technology transfer from fundamental research to industrial practices. The US-Germany network will train the next cadre of "whole-brain" researchers in the global context. In addition, the synergy adds value to both research communities.
